intro: Adelobotrys ciliatus, commonly known as the hairy bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its hairy stems and pods. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in open habitats such as roadsides and fields. Its small, pea-like flowers are usually pink or purple, and it produces inflated, hairy pods that contain several seeds. Adelobotrys ciliatus is an annual plant that plays a role in soil stabilization and provides nectar for pollinators.
